channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: [Virtual Event] Shields Up: Key Technologies Reshaping Cybersecurity Defenses
Fake CAPTCHA Scam Tricks Windows Users Into Installing Malware
item.description: <p>A fake CAPTCHA scam is tricking Windows users into running PowerShell commands that install StealC malware and steal passwords, crypto wallets, and more.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-fake-captcha-scam-stealc-malware-windows/">Fake CAPTCHA Scam Tricks Windows Users Into Installing Malware</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Infostealer Steals OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Files and Gateway Tokens
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers disclosed they have detected a case of an information stealer infection successfully exfiltrating a victim's OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot and Moltbot) configuration environment. "This finding marks a significant milestone in the evolution of infostealer behavior: the transition from stealing browser credentials to harvesting the 'souls' and identities of personal AI [
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Study Uncovers 25 Password Recovery Attacks in Major Cloud Password Managers
item.description: A new study has found that multiple cloud-based password managers, including Bitwarden, Dashlane, and LastPass, are susceptible to password recovery attacks under certain conditions. "The attacks range in severity from integrity violations to the complete compromise of all vaults in an organization," researchers Matteo Scarlata, Giovanni Torrisi, Matilda Backendal, and Kenneth G. Paterson said.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Operation DoppelBrand: Weaponizing Fortune 500 Brands
item.description: The GS7 cyberthreat group targets US financial institutions with near-perfect imitations of corporate portals to steal credentials and gain remote access.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Vulnerabilities in Password Managers Allow Hackers to View and Change Passwords
item.description: Security researchers have challenged end-to-end encryption claims from popular commercial password managers

item.title: Fake ‘Antivirus’ App Spreads Android Malware, Steals Banking Credentials
item.description: <p>A fake Android antivirus app called TrustBastion is spreading malware and stealing banking credentials. Here’s how it works and how to stay protected.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-fake-android-antivirus-trustbastion-malware/">Fake &#8216;Antivirus&#8217; App Spreads Android Malware, Steals Banking Credentials</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: SMEs Wrong to Assume They Won’t Be Hit by Cyber-Attacks, NCSC Boss Warns
item.description: NCSC’s Richard Horne has warned that cybercriminals do not care about business size and called for SMEs to act now to secure their organizations

item.title: OysterLoader Evolves With New C2 Infrastructure and Obfuscation
item.description: OysterLoader malware evolves into 2026, refining C2 infrastructure, obfuscation & infection stages

item.title: Operation DoppelBrand Weaponizes Trusted Brands For Credential Theft
item.description: New phishing campaign dubbed Operation DoppelBrand targeted major financial firms like Wells Fargo

item.title: 260K+ Chrome Users Duped by Fake AI Browser Extensions
item.description: 30 copycat apps tricked users, and Google itself, into thinking they're legitimate AI tools.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Weekly Recap: Outlook Add-Ins Hijack, 0-Day Patches, Wormable Botnet & AI Malware
item.description: This week’s recap shows how small gaps are turning into big entry points. Not always through new exploits, often through tools, add-ons, cloud setups, or workflows that people already trust and rarely question. Another signal: attackers are mixing old and new methods. Legacy botnet tactics, modern cloud abuse, AI assistance, and supply-chain exposure are being used side by side, whichever path
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The Promptware Kill Chain
item.description: <p><a href="https://www.schneier.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/promptware-kill-chain.jpg"><img alt="The promptware kill chain: initial access, privilege escalation, reconnaissance, persistence, command &#38; control, lateral movement, action on objective" src="https://www.schneier.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/promptware-kill-chain-660w.jpg" /></a></p> <p>Attacks against modern generative artificial intelligence (AI) large language models (LLMs) pose a real threat. Yet discussions around these attacks and their potential defenses are dangerously myopic. The dominant narrative focuses on &#8220;<a href="https://simonwillison.net/2022/Sep/12/prompt-injection/">prompt injection</a>,&#8221; a set of techniques to embed instructions into inputs to LLM intended to perform malicious activity. This term suggests a simple, singular vulnerability. This framing obscures a more complex and dangerous reality. Attacks on LLM-based systems have evolved into a distinct class of malware execution mechanisms, which we term &#8220;promptware.&#8221; In a ...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Safe and Inclusive E‑Society: How Lithuania Is Bracing for AI‑Driven Cyber Fraud
item.description:
Presentation of the KTU Consortium Mission ‘A Safe and Inclusive Digital Society’ at the Innovation Agency event ‘Innovation Breakfast: How Mission-Oriented Science and Innovation Programmes Will Address Societal Challenges’.
Technologies are evolving fast, reshaping economies, governance, and daily life. Yet, as innovation accelerates, so do digital risks. Technological change is no longer
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New ZeroDayRAT Mobile Spyware Enables Real-Time Surveillance and Data Theft
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new mobile spyware platform dubbed ZeroDayRAT that's being advertised on Telegram as a way to grab sensitive data and facilitate real-time surveillance on Android and iOS devices. "The developer runs dedicated channels for sales, customer support, and regular updates, giving buyers a single point of access to a fully operational spyware
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Odido Breach Impacts Millions of Dutch Telco Users
item.description: Dutch telco Odido has revealed a major data breach impacting over six million customers

item.title: New Chrome Zero-Day (CVE-2026-2441) Under Active Attack — Patch Released
item.description: Google on Friday released security updates for its Chrome browser to address a security flaw that it said has been exploited in the wild. The high-severity vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-2441 (CVSS score: 8.8), has been described as a use-after-free bug in CSS. Security researcher Shaheen Fazim has been credited with discovering and reporting the shortcoming on February 11, 2026. "Use after
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Discloses DNS-Based ClickFix Attack Using Nslookup for Malware Staging
item.description: Microsoft has disclosed details of a new version of the ClickFix social engineering tactic in which the attackers trick unsuspecting users into running commands that carry out a Domain Name System (DNS) lookup to retrieve the next-stage payload. Specifically, the attack relies on using the "nslookup" (short for nameserver lookup) command to execute a custom DNS lookup triggered via the Windows
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Upcoming Speaking Engagements
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Viral AI Caricatures Highlight Shadow AI Dangers
item.description: <p>A viral AI caricature trend may be exposing sensitive enterprise data, fueling shadow AI risks, social engineering attacks, and LLM account compromise.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ai-caricature-trend-shadow-ai-security-risks/">Viral AI Caricatures Highlight Shadow AI Dangers</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: Google Ties Suspected Russian Actor to CANFAIL Malware Attacks on Ukrainian Orgs
item.description: A previously undocumented threat actor has been attributed to attacks targeting Ukrainian organizations with malware known as CANFAIL. Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) described the hacking group as possibly affiliated with Russian intelligence services. The threat actor is assessed to have targeted defense, military, government, and energy organizations within the Ukrainian regional and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Under Pressure to Bolster Defenses for BYOVD Attacks
item.description: Threat actors are exploiting security gaps to weaponize Windows drivers and terminate security processes in targeted networks, and there may be no easy fixes in sight.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Nation-State Hackers Put Defense Industrial Base Under Siege
item.description: Espionage groups from China, Russia and other nations burned at least two dozen zero-days in edge devices in attempts to infiltrate defense contractors' networks.

item.description: As AI deployments scale and start to include packs of agents autonomously working in concert, organizations face a naturally amplified attack surface.

item.title: Google Links China, Iran, Russia, North Korea to Coordinated Defense Sector Cyber Operations
item.description: Several state-sponsored actors, hacktivist entities, and criminal groups from China, Iran, North Korea, and Russia have trained their sights on the defense industrial base (DIB) sector, according to findings from Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG). The tech giant's threat intelligence division said the adversarial targeting of the sector is centered around four key themes: striking defense
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ransomware Groups Claimed 2,000 Attacks in Just Three Months
item.description: <p>Ransomware attacks surged 52% in 2025, with supply chain breaches nearly doubling as groups like Qilin drive record monthly incidents worldwide.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ransomware-attacks-surge-2025/">Ransomware Groups Claimed 2,000 Attacks in Just Three Months</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Drew Robb

item.title: UAT-9921 Deploys VoidLink Malware to Target Technology and Financial Sectors
item.description: A previously unknown threat actor tracked as UAT-9921 has been observed leveraging a new modular framework called VoidLink in its campaigns targeting the technology and financial services sectors, according to findings from Cisco Talos. "This threat actor seems to have been active since 2019, although they have not necessarily used VoidLink over the duration of their activity," researchers Nick
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Munich Security Conference: Cyber Threats Lead G7 Risk Index, Disinformation Ranks Third
item.description: G7 countries ranked cyber-attacks as the top risk, while BICS members placed cyber threats only as the eighth most pressing risk

item.title: Malicious Chrome Extensions Caught Stealing Business Data, Emails, and Browsing History
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a malicious Google Chrome extension that's designed to steal data associated with Meta Business Suite and Facebook Business Manager. The extension, named CL Suite by @CLMasters (ID: jkphinfhmfkckkcnifhjiplhfoiefffl), is marketed as a way to scrape Meta Business Suite data, remove verification pop-ups, and generate two-factor authentication (2FA) codes.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fake AI Assistants in Google Chrome Web Store Steal Passwords and Spy on Emails
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of users have downloaded malicious AI extensions masquerading as ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok and others, warn cybersecurity researchers at LayerX

item.title: npm’s Update to Harden Their Supply Chain, and Points to Consider
item.description: In December 2025, in response to the Sha1-Hulud incident, npm completed a major authentication overhaul intended to reduce supply-chain attacks. While the overhaul is a solid step forward, the changes don’t make npm projects immune from supply-chain attacks. npm is still susceptible to malware attacks – here’s what you need to know for a safer Node community. Let’s start with the original
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Observe In-the-Wild Exploitation of BeyondTrust CVSS 9.9 Vulnerability
item.description: Threat actors have started to exploit a recently disclosed critical security flaw impacting BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products, according to watchTowr. "Overnight we observed first in-the-wild exploitation of BeyondTrust across our global sensors," Ryan Dewhurst, head of threat intelligence at watchTowr, said in a post on X. "Attackers are abusing
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: It's time to phase out the &quot;patch and pray&quot; approach, eliminate needless public interfaces, and enforce authentication controls, one expert says.

item.description: <p>Apple urges users to update after patching CVE-2026-20700, a zero-day flaw exploited in sophisticated targeted attacks across multiple devices.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-zero-day-cve-update-february-2026/">Critical Apple Flaw Exploited in ‘Sophisticated’ Attacks, Company Urges Rapid Patching</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.description: Men should take extra care on Valentine’s Day because they are nearly twice as likely as women to fall victim to romance scams.

item.description: Microsoft uncovered AI recommendation poisoning in 31 companies across 14 industries, and turnkey tools make it trivially easy to pull off.

item.title: Microsoft’s February Patch Tuesday Fixes 6 Zero-Days Under Attack

item.description: Google on Thursday said it observed the North Korea-linked threat actor known as UNC2970 using its generative artificial intelligence (AI) model Gemini to conduct reconnaissance on its targets, as various hacking groups continue to weaponize the tool for accelerating various phases of the cyber attack life cycle, enabling information operations, and even conducting model extraction attacks. item.title: 3D Printer Surveillance
item.description: <p>New York is <a href="https://blog.adafruit.com/2026/02/03/new-york-wants-to-ctrlaltdelete-your-3d-printer/">contemplating</a> a bill that adds surveillance to 3D printers:</p> <blockquote><p>New York’s 2026­2027 executive budget bill (S.9005 / A.10005) includes language that should alarm every maker, educator, and small manufacturer in the state. Buried in Part C is a provision requiring all 3D printers sold or delivered in New York to include &#8220;blocking technology.&#8221; This is defined as software or firmware that <i>scans every print file</i> through a &#8220;firearms blueprint detection algorithm&#8221; and refuses to print anything it flags as a potential firearm or firearm component...</i></p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: AI Prompt RCE, Claude 0-Click, RenEngine Loader, Auto 0-Days & 25+ Stories
item.description: Threat activity this week shows one consistent signal — attackers are leaning harder on what already works. Instead of flashy new exploits, many operations are built around quiet misuse of trusted tools, familiar workflows, and overlooked exposures that sit in plain sight. Another shift is how access is gained versus how it’s used. Initial entry points are getting simpler, while post-compromise
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI Skills Represent Dangerous New Attack Surface, Says TrendAI
item.description: New TrendAI report warns that most security tools can’t protect against attacks on AI skills artifacts

item.title: The CTEM Divide: Why 84% of Security Programs Are Falling Behind
item.description: A new 2026 market intelligence study of 128 enterprise security decision-makers (available here) reveals a stark divide forming between organizations – one that has nothing to do with budget size or industry and everything to do with a single framework decision. Organizations implementing Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM) demonstrate 50% better attack surface visibility, 23-point
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

Threat intelligence firm GreyNoise said it recorded 417 exploitation sessions from 8 unique source IP addresses between February 1 and 9, 2026. An estimated 346
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-20700 (CVSS score: 7.8), has been described as a memory corruption issue in dyld, Apple's Dynamic Link Editor. Successful exploitation of the vulnerability could allow an
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Patches Windows Flaw Causing VPN Disruptions
item.description: <p>Microsoft patches CVE-2026-21525, an actively exploited RasMan flaw that can crash Windows VPN services and disrupt remote access.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-rasman-cve-vpn/">Microsoft Patches Windows Flaw Causing VPN Disruptions</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: North Korea's UNC1069 Hammers Crypto Firms With AI
item.description: In moving away from traditional banks to focus on Web3 companies, the threat actor is leveraging LLMs, deepfakes, legitimate platforms, and ClickFix.

item.title: First Malicious Outlook Add-In Found Stealing 4,000+ Microsoft Credentials
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered what they said is the first known malicious Microsoft Outlook add-in detected in the wild. In this unusual supply chain attack detailed by Koi Security, an unknown attacker claimed the domain associated with a now-abandoned legitimate add-in to serve a fake Microsoft login page, stealing over 4,000 credentials in the process. The activity has been
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: From 10M to 25M: Conduent Breach Balloons Into One of 2025’s Largest
item.description: <p>The Conduent ransomware attack has grown to impact 25 million Americans, exposing Social Security numbers and medical data in one of 2025’s largest breaches.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-conduent-ransomware-breach-25m/">From 10M to 25M: Conduent Breach Balloons Into One of 2025’s Largest</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: North Korean Hackers Use Deepfake Video Calls to Target Crypto Firms
item.description: Campaign combines stolen Telegram accounts, fake Zoom calls and ClickFix attacks to deploy infostealer malware

item.title: Kimwolf Botnet Swamps Anonymity Network I2P
item.description: For the past week, the massive "Internet of Things" (IoT) botnet known as Kimwolf has been disrupting the The Invisible Internet Project (I2P), a decentralized, encrypted communications network designed to anonymize and secure online communications. I2P users started reporting disruptions in the network around the same time the Kimwolf botmasters began relying on it to evade takedown attempts against the botnet's control servers.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: APT36 and SideCopy Launch Cross-Platform RAT Campaigns Against Indian Entities
item.description: Indian defense sector and government-aligned organizations have been targeted by multiple campaigns that are designed to compromise Windows and Linux environments with remote access trojans capable of stealing sensitive data and ensuring continued access to infected machines. The campaigns are characterized by the use of malware families like Geta RAT, Ares RAT, and DeskRAT, which are often
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Rewiring Democracy Ebook is on Sale
item.description: <p>I just noticed that the ebook version of <a href="https://www.schneier.com/books/rewiring-democracy/"><cite>Rewiring Democracy</cite></a> is on sale for $5 on <a href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0DTNZ2H86">Amazon</a>, <a href="https://books.apple.com/us/book/rewiring-democracy/id6740839808">Apple Books</a>, <a href="https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/rewiring-democracy-bruce-schneier/1146990469?ean=9780262384407">Barnes &#38; Noble</a>, <a href="https://www.booksamillion.com/p/Rewiring-Democracy/Bruce-Schneier/Q247907742">Books A Million</a>, <a href="https://play.google.com/store/books/details?id=QcNAEQAAQBAJ">Google Play</a>, <a href="https://www.kobo.com/us/en/ebook/rewiring-democracy">Kobo</a>, and presumably everywhere else in the US. I have no idea how long this will last.</p> <p>Also, Amazon has a <a href="https://www.amazon.com/Rewiring-Democracy-Transform-Government-Citizenship/dp/0262049945">coupon</a> that brings the hardcover price down to $20. You&#8217;ll see the discount at checkout.</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

Microsoft issued fixes for 59 flaws, including six actively exploited zero-days in various Windows components that could be abused to bypass security features, escalate privileges, and trigger a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. Elsewhere
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: US Court Hands Crypto Scammer 20 Years in $73m Case
item.description: A federal court has sentenced crypto-scammer Daren Li to 20 years in absentia

item.title: Prompt Injection Via Road Signs
item.description: <p>Interesting research: &#8220;<a href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/2510.00181">CHAI: Command Hijacking Against Embodied AI</a>.&#8221;</p> <blockquote><p><b>Abstract:</b> Embodied Artificial Intelligence (AI) promises to handle edge cases in robotic vehicle systems where data is scarce by using common-sense reasoning grounded in perception and action to generalize beyond training distributions and adapt to novel real-world situations. These capabilities, however, also create new security risks. In this paper, we introduce CHAI (Command Hijacking against embodied AI), a new class of prompt-based attacks that exploit the multimodal language interpretation abilities of Large Visual-Language Models (LVLMs). CHAI embeds deceptive natural language instructions, such as misleading signs, in visual input, systematically searches the token space, builds a dictionary of prompts, and guides an attacker model to generate Visual Attack Prompts. We evaluate CHAI on four LVLM agents; drone emergency landing, autonomous driving, and aerial object tracking, and on a real robotic vehicle. Our experiments show that CHAI consistently outperforms state-of-the-art attacks. By exploiting the semantic and multimodal reasoning strengths of next-generation embodied AI systems, CHAI underscores the urgent need for defenses that extend beyond traditional adversarial robustness...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: FIRST Forecasts Record-Breaking 50,000+ CVEs in 2026
item.description: This year should break all the records in terms of vulnerability disclosed, reaching or even surpassing 50,000 new CVEs disclosed

item.title: Exposed Training Open the Door for Crypto-Mining in Fortune 500 Cloud Environments
item.description: Intentionally vulnerable training applications are widely used for security education, internal testing, and product demonstrations. Tools such as OWASP Juice Shop, DVWA, Hackazon, and bWAPP are designed to be insecure by default, making them useful for learning how common attack techniques work in controlled environments. The issue is not the applications themselves, but how they are often
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Patches 59 Vulnerabilities Including Six Actively Exploited Zero-Days
item.description: Microsoft on Tuesday released security updates to address a set of 59 flaws across its software, including six vulnerabilities that it said have been exploited in the wild. Of the 59 flaws, five are rated Critical, 52 are rated Important, and two are rated Moderate in severity. Twenty-five of the patched vulnerabilities have been classified as privilege escalation, followed by remote code
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: SSHStalker Botnet Uses IRC C2 to Control Linux Systems via Legacy Kernel Exploits
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new botnet operation called SSHStalker that relies on the Internet Relay Chat (IRC) communication protocol for command-and-control (C2) purposes. "The toolset blends stealth helpers with legacy-era Linux exploitation: Alongside log cleaners (utmp/wtmp/lastlog tampering) and rootkit-class artifacts, the actor keeps a large back-catalog of
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Fixes Six Zero Day Vulnerability in February Patch Tuesday
item.description: Six actively exploited zero-day bug have been patched by Microsoft

item.title: North Korea-Linked UNC1069 Uses AI Lures to Attack Cryptocurrency Organizations
item.description: The North Korea-linked threat actor known as UNC1069 has been observed targeting the cryptocurrency sector to steal sensitive data from Windows and macOS systems with the ultimate goal of facilitating financial theft. "The intrusion relied on a social engineering scheme involving a compromised Telegram account, a fake Zoom meeting, a ClickFix infection vector, and reported usage of AI-generated
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Asia Fumbles With Throttling Back Telnet Traffic in Region
item.description: Only Taiwan made the top 10 list of governments, effectively blocking the threat-ridden protocol, but overall, the region lagged in curbing Telnet traffic.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: SolarWinds WHD Attacks Highlight Risks of Exposed Apps
item.description: Organizations that have exposed their instances of Web Help Desk to the public Internet have inadvertently made them prime targets for attackers.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Patch Tuesday, February 2026 Edition
item.description: Microsoft today released updates to fix more than 50 security holes in its Windows operating systems and other software, including patches for a whopping six "zero-day" vulnerabilities that attackers are already exploiting in the wild.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: In Bypassing MFA, ZeroDayRAT Is 'Textbook Stalkerware'
item.description: With access to SIM, location data, and a preview of recent SMSes, attackers have everything they need for account takeover or targeted social engineering.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Microsoft Patches 6 Actively Exploited Zero-Days
item.description: Three of those zero-days are security feature bypass flaws, which give attackers a way to slip past built-in protections in multiple Microsoft products.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: 10K Claude Desktop Users Exposed by Zero-Click Vulnerability
item.description: <p>A zero-click flaw in Anthropic’s Claude Desktop Extensions allows attackers to trigger remote code execution via Google Calendar events.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-claude-desktop-zero-click-vulnerability/">10K Claude Desktop Users Exposed by Zero-Click Vulnerability</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: DPRK Operatives Impersonate Professionals on LinkedIn to Infiltrate Companies
item.description: The information technology (IT) workers associated with the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) are now applying to remote positions using real LinkedIn accounts of individuals they're impersonating, marking a new escalation of the fraudulent scheme. "These profiles often have verified workplace emails and identity badges, which DPRK operatives hope will make their fraudulent
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: OT Attacks Get Scary With 'Living-off-the-Plant' Techniques
item.description: Ironically, security by obscurity has helped prevent dangerous OT attacks in recent years. It won't be that way forever.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Phorpiex Phishing Delivers Low-Noise Global Group Ransomware
item.description: High-volume phishing campaign delivers Phorpiex malware via malicious Windows Shortcut files

item.title: Reynolds Ransomware Embeds BYOVD Driver to Disable EDR Security Tools
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of an emergent ransomware family dubbed Reynolds that comes embedded with a built-in bring your own vulnerable driver (BYOVD) component for defense evasion purposes within the ransomware payload itself. BYOVD refers to an adversarial technique that abuses legitimate but flawed driver software to escalate privileges and disable Endpoint Detection
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: “Digital Parasite” Warning as Attackers Favor Stealth for Extortion
item.description: Picus Security warns of the increasingly sophisticated ways malicious activity is staying hidden

item.title: New Mobile Spyware ZeroDayRAT Targets Android and iOS
item.description: ZeroDayRAT is a new mobile spyware targeting Android and iOS, offering attackers persistent access

item.title: From Ransomware to Residency: Inside the Rise of the Digital Parasite
item.description: Are ransomware and encryption still the defining signals of modern cyberattacks, or has the industry been too fixated on noise while missing a more dangerous shift happening quietly all around them? According to Picus Labs’ new Red Report 2026, which analyzed over 1.1 million malicious files and mapped 15.5 million adversarial actions observed across 2025, attackers are no longer optimizing for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fortinet Patches Critical SQLi Flaw Enabling Unauthenticated Code Execution
item.description:
Fortinet has released security updates to address a critical flaw impacting FortiClientEMS that could lead to the execution of arbitrary code on susceptible systems. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-21643, has a CVSS rating of 9.1 out of a maximum of 10.0.
"An improper neutralization of special elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') vulnerability [CWE-89] in FortiClientEMS may
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Singapore Takes Down Chinese Hackers Targeting Telco Networks
item.description: Operation Cyber Guardian was Singapore’s largest and longest running anti-cyber threat law enforcement operation

item.title: AI-Generated Text and the Detection Arms Race
item.description: <p>In 2023, the science fiction literary magazine <cite>Clarkesworld</cite> <a href="https://www.npr.org/2023/02/24/1159286436/ai-chatbot-chatgpt-magazine-clarkesworld-artificial-intelligence">stopped accepting</a> new submissions because so many were generated by artificial intelligence. Near as the editors could tell, many submitters pasted the magazine’s detailed story guidelines into an AI and sent in the results. And they weren’t alone. Other fiction magazines have also <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/2/25/23613752/ai-generated-short-stories-literary-magazines-clarkesworld-science-fiction">reported a high number</a> of AI-generated submissions.</p> <p>This is only one example of a ubiquitous trend. A legacy system relied on the difficulty of writing and cognition to limit volume. Generative AI overwhelms the system because the humans on the receiving end can’t keep up...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: NCSC Issues Warning Over “Severe” Cyber-Attacks Targeting Critical National Infrastructure
item.description: NCSC call firms to ‘act now’ following disruptive malware attacks targeting Polish energy providers

item.title: ZAST.AI Raises $6M Pre-A to Scale "Zero False Positive" AI-Powered Code Security
item.description: January 5, 2026, Seattle, USA — ZAST.AI announced the completion of a $6 million Pre-A funding round. This investment came from the well-known investment firm Hillhouse Capital, bringing ZAST.AI's total funding close to $10 million. This marks a recognition from leading capital markets of a new solution: ending the era of high false positive rates in security tools and making every alert
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Warlock Ransomware Breaches SmarterTools Through Unpatched SmarterMail Server
item.description: SmarterTools confirmed last week that the Warlock (aka Storm-2603) ransomware gang breached its network by exploiting an unpatched SmarterMail instance. The incident took place on January 29, 2026, when a mail server that was not updated to the latest version was compromised, the company's Chief Commercial Officer, Derek Curtis, said. "Prior to the breach, we had approximately 30 servers/VMs
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
